text: If you haven't read it before, this is a great thread <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/6113>

elements.text: If you haven't read it before, this is a great thread

text: I have read it. The conclusion I came to is "if Julia doesn't have dependent types, it can only be because your definition of type is so narrow that Julia doesn't have types at all"

attachments.title: What is dependent typing?
attachments.text: Can someone explain dependent typing to me? I have little experience in Haskell, Cayenne, Epigram, or other functional languages, so the simpler of terms you can use, the more I will appreciate it!
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: What is dependent typing?

elements.text: Here's a nice understandable example from StackOverflow:

text:
And the corresponding julia code
```julia> struct BoundedInt{n} <: Integer
           i::Int
           function BoundedInt{n}(i) where {n}
               @assert i <= n
               new{n}(i)
           end
       end

julia> min(i::Int, j::Int)::BoundedInt{j} = i < j ? i : j
min (generic function with 1 method)

julia> min(1, 2)
BoundedInt{2}(1)

julia> min(3, 2)
BoundedInt{2}(2)```

elements.text:
julia> struct BoundedInt{n} <: Integer
           i::Int
           function BoundedInt{n}(i) where {n}
               @assert i <= n
               new{n}(i)
           end
       end

julia> min(i::Int, j::Int)::BoundedInt{j} = i < j ? i : j
min (generic function with 1 method)

julia> min(1, 2)
BoundedInt{2}(1)

julia> min(3, 2)
BoundedInt{2}(2)

text:
Although Julia is my favorite language, I have to say, "No, we don't have dependent types."
*EDIT*: it's an old issue and has been extensively discussed. I'd agree with the point that dependent typing eases some problems, and its seemingly counterpart in Julia(not not the same thing at all) addresses others.

text: What makes you say there are no dependant types in julia? Is the above not a textbook example of a dependant type?
